comments.commentBody: I was so disappointed when "Terriers" was not picked up for a second season.

This article and the comments remind me of my round-trip Trailways bus ride between Virginia and Arizona when I was a college student in the 80s.  It was a wonderful adventure.  I met fascinating, kind, friendly people from all walks of life and saw amazing scenery.  It did seem like 3 days in Texas, but it was interesting to see firsthand (for the first time, anyway - I took an alternate route home!).  Ever since that trip, I've wished I had the time to take the bus so I could meet interesting people and enjoy the  scenery.  I don't know about taking Megabus for overnight trips - I might stick with Greyhound.

My experiences with Megabus between Montgomery and New Orleans have been very good, and I appreciate it as a cheap, pleasant option to driving myself. (Interstate driving is tedious and boring.)  Learned early on to bring a light jacket and sit away from the vents that blast the cold AC in the summer. My fellow passengers have always been courteous and accommodating. The drivers have been mostly excellent.

MPH--ditto!  It's about time our penal system got fixed, it's broken.  We incarcerate more than any country in the world!  Eastern countries use positive reinforcement while we still use punishment--is it working?  We can't build prisons fast enough to house inmates.   Fix it instead of putting a band aid on it and adding to this country's high mental health stats!

Scott, you are surely mixed up?  Take a few criminal justice courses.  Why is solitary confinement for 10 years okay?  Why should I foot the bill to hold someone in prison with no chance of rehabilitation for 10 years when capital punishment could resolve the long wait and $ ?  Do you have any idea how overcrowded our prisons are now?  We can't build them fast enough!  Empty prisons of the least dangerous criminals and put them in rehab.   Then medium security and max security level prisoners will have room with getting stressed and anxiety ridden due to overcrowded conditions to alleviate fighting and rioting.  Don't hold people on death row for 5, 10, 20 years as we do today.  If that's their sentence, carry it out within 2 years.  Those meant for solitary, make them work!   Painting, plumbing, moving, building, teaching, anything and everything to keep them busy.   Save tax payers money by not paying them a dime, and save even more by replacing these criminals in positions of those we now pay.

I distrust any politician that talks about how they are going to bring people together. I can't even imagine what this means other than "I'm going to bring the people who are for me together in voting for me." I remember another "uniter" and all that uniting went out in a handbasket. And the current government has done everything it can on both sides to keep from "uniting." Presidents may want it, but until Congresspeople start doing what's right for the country even if it costs them their jobs, nothing--absolutely nothing--will change.

In that sense I'm not comparing Iran to the Nazi's.  I'm saying that the Iranian government does not exactly have a record of keeping their word.  Their motives are not peaceful.  They will cheat and once they do it will be very difficult to put sanctions back on.  Once they acquire some fancier weapons they'll lob one at Israel and World War III will begin.

It's full of what-ifs and maybes. Feels little different than Jim's "scientific reticence" period? I'm waiting until I hear from a few more independent researchers. Listen to the press call he did to get a full sense of the concerns.

For what it is worth, my take on this paper is exactly that where it is published, on Atmos. Chem. Phys. Disc. -- is appropriate and telling. It is intended as a provoking idea.

What gives it some credence from external evidence is the Eemian, but our ability to diagnose rates of sea-level rise in the Eemian are not as good as we'd like, and the question of whether the Eemian mechanisms are a good-enough analogy to today is arguable (and being argued.)

I got a copy and read it reasonably carefully, I'm not expert enough in the specific issues to add a comment to the journal, will leave that for others (and they surely will).

I will be interested to see what scientific consensus emerges after a year or two, including a lot more work and analysis. One outcome might be a reasonably strong conclusion that this hypothesis can be rejected with reasonably strong confidence. I'll be a bit surprised if that happens though. My guess, FWIW, is that it will end up being seen as lower-probability, but cannot be ruled out.

And that will be worrisome, no other way around it.

An Alarming Sea Level Scenario
http://www.washingtonpost.com/news/energy-environment/wp/2015/07/20/the-...

In the new study, Hansen and his colleagues suggest that the “doubling time” for ice loss from West Antarctica — the time period over which the amount of loss could double — could be as short as 10 years. In other words, a non-linear process could be at work, triggering major sea level rise in a time frame of 50 to 200 years. By contrast, Hansen and colleagues note, the IPCC assumed more of a linear process, suggesting only around 1 meter of sea level rise, at most, by 2100...

Using climate models and an analogy with the so-called Eemian period or “Marine isotope stage 5e” — an interglacial period some 120,000 years ago that featured considerable sea level rise — the paper goes on to suggest that major ice loss from both Antarctica and Greenland will change the circulation of the oceans, as large volumes of cold, fresh water pour into the seas. This freshening or decreasing saltiness of the ocean, at both poles, could ultimately block the oceans’ overturning circulation, in which (in the northern hemisphere) warm water travels northward, and then colder, denser water sinks and travels back south again.

The Eemian, the research suggests, may have only reached global average temperatures about 1 degree Celsius warmer than today — but nonetheless, featured these major changes.

James Hansen (the man who gets the denialists into a foaming rage second only to Michael Mann) and colleagues have come out with a paper released to the EGU Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics Discussion, which argues on the basis of modeling that sea-level rise could proceed far more quickly that current forecasts. These issues are not my specialty and there is excellent scientific discussion/criticism started ... and sure to continue.

The WaPo and others have already picked this up, surprised the NY Times has not, but probably will have by the time you can read this....

I grew up 9 miles from Jeffrey's Bay (J-Bay) which was a quiet fishing village with a beautiful beach and body-surfed there to my heart's content as a teenager ca. 1956-1961 at least once a week October thru January, with never a care about sharks. The beach didn't even have lifeguards, and oar and sail powered fishing boats that put hawkers with fresh fish on the streets of Humansdorp by 5 PM every day were all beached on one side. They were all manned by what we called Cape Coloureds (brown people of mixed race).
I was in College in the US when my mother wrote me about Americans who had said they found a perfect wave near Cape St. Francis (about 6 mi SSW of J-Bay) I dismissed it it as politesse, until I saw "The Endless Summer" after it debuted in 1966, and there at, the end of the movie Cape St. Francis was indeed the locastion of T.P.Wave! Years later my cousin, an avid kayak surfer told me they had found better waves closer to J-Bay. That whole stretch of coast is now prime vacation real estate, and all thanks to two surfer dudes.
Since i do not recall any shark sightings while I lived there, I wonder if global warming has something to do with it.

Dear Dr. Harrison,

The 0.1 C per century trend is for the "hiatus" period of 1998-2014 as measured by virtually all the credible data bases including HadCRUT4, UAH, and RSS.

Karl et al is an outlier to claim 0.106 per decade in this period and has been much criticized for doing so. I do not "admit" 1 C per century; I quote Karl et al, a committed alarmist, as saying that this is the long-term rate since the middle of the 20th century.

So even a committed alarmist such as Karl calculates the long term rate as no more than about 1 C/100 y. The short term rate is 0.1 degrees C per century, which indicates that there is no acceleration but rather a decrease in rate.

Therefore, where is the catastrophic warming?

The argument has always been that rates of global warming are faster than anything the biosphere has ever endured before, and that therefore catastrophe is at hand. On the contrary, rates of warming are moderate and, in the short term, decreasing.

Where is the catastrophe in that?

And why are short term warming rates decreasing at a time when CO2 emissions are increasing?

Natural variability has obviously overwhelmed the CO2 effect over these years.

Therefore the CO2 effect must be much smaller than assumed by the CAGW Prophets of Doom.

See P. J. Michaels' July 22, 2015 testimony to the US House of Representatives regarding climate sensitivity and the failure of models compared to observations.

When announcing the annual World Meteorological Organization climate report in March 2014, the WMO secretary-general Michel Jarraud said that there had been no pause, with 2013 continuing a long-term warming trend showing "no standstill in global warming". 2013 had been the sixth warmest year on record [2014 likely the first, and 2015 on pace to break that record], and 13 of the 14 warmest years on record [14 of the 15 now] had occurred since the start of 2000. He said that "The warming of our oceans has accelerated, and at lower depths. More than 90 percent of the excess energy trapped by greenhouse gases is stored in the oceans."

The report itself stated that "While the rate at which surface air temperatures are rising has slowed in recent years, heat continues to be trapped in the Earth system, mostly as increased ocean heat content. About 93 per cent of the excess heat trapped in the Earth system between 1971 and 2010 was taken up by the ocean." From 2000 to 2013 the oceans had gained around three times as much heat as in the preceding 20 years, and while before 2000 most of the heat had been trapped between the sea surface and 700 metres (2,300 ft) depth, from 2000 to 2013 most heat had been stored between 700 and 2,000 metres (6,600 ft) depth.

Below Dale repeats the current denialist talking-point argument, and sadly I presume he is repeating something he got off some blog site without checking:

"So global warming is going up at a rate of 0.1 degrees C per century. Ho-hum.

The latest HADCRUT4 trend is +0.013 degrees C per decade. The Argo array 700-1500 m ocean trend is +0.0013 degrees C/year. And the latest Karl et al paper claimed +0.116 degrees C /decade, unchanged since the 1950's.

Are you really in a panic about 0.1 degree C/century?"

And this is all "the pause, the pause, did I tell you about the pause?" ... with a little extra obfuscation, and lying.

Take HADCRUT4 or any of the reputable temperature series and one will see close to 1°C from 1900 to 2000, and a rate which is more than double that after 1950.

The deep oceans are warming more slowly AS EXPECTED, limited heat transfer into lots of heat capacity. Your point in mentioning this is what? To cite some smaller number from somewhere?

But then the big whopper is the claim about Karl et al. -- it says nothing of the sort -- I do Dale the courtesy of believing that he is repeating something he didn't check. The abstract states:

"the central estimate for the rate of warming during the first 15 years of the 21st century is at least as great as the last half of the 20th century."

That's about 2° C per century.
